column1: False advertising.
Amazon does not honor their own promotions.
Poor customer services.
Amazon lately has been showing items as two days ship when I order and a day or two later they still have not shipped. This is ridiculous as it is not even the Holiday yet or BF.
Very Disappointed at the level of service I have received from Amazon.
I will never do business with them again
Good luck and look elsewhere, only order here if you have to.
"Prime" items are consistently way overpriced.

As a loyal customer, the first time i filed a claim with Amazon was so disappointed and unhappy. My returned product was delivered to the seller according to USPS tracking information, however, the seller said they just received a box without ring inside after 7 days they received the mail. The reason i made the returned because the seller didn't attach the IGI Certification as promised, which is so important evidence to approve the quality of diamond. however, Amazon denied my claim to protect their seller, why don't they protect their customers who believe in Amazon's reputation so purchase from the 3rd party.

Well it is nice that I can pretty much order anything with one click and it is usually reasonably priced.........my problem is the shipping.  i live in the country so unless its UPS GROUND or FEDEX. USPS and UPS sure post do not have a route to my physical address so the product gets dropped off at the post office for me to pick up.  while that might be an easy situation for most, it's not for me. Our post office which is on the otherside of BFE from where I live is only open 3 hours a day...............yes just 3.  3 while I am at work making money to pay for the products I don't have access to.  I have literally had this happen to 9 out of the last 12 orders!!!!!! and amazon keeps telling me they are making notes on my account, some "special" forms where filled out and yet it still happens.  Just like today....so I will spend 2 hours tonight on the phone with customer service AGAIN just to have nothing done about it AGAIN.  I'm done with amazon $99 a year is too much for this crap! So basically if the post office won't deliver to your house DO NOT order from Amazon because you will be right next to me, up a creek with no paddle!!!!!

Ordered an OTG cable and a USB hub on 3rd October; should have received them by 12th Oct. Have called Amazon 6-8 times now and every time they say that I will receive them within 24 hrs. The stupid carrier - Ecom Express doesn't even pick up calls. First the tracker said that the delivery went to some wrong hub by mistake, then it wrongfully said that it was delivered but I was not there to receive. To top it all, then the tracker said that I have called and asked that my order be delayed. It is 28th October today and I have lost all hope. Thanks a lot Amazon. In case someone didn't understood all that and the intended sarcasm, allow me to be rather blunt. AMAZON SUCKS. "Earth's  Most  Customer- Centric Company" the slogan of Amazon?? ..... BS

I made a purchase on 7/29/2015 for an item Amazom.com showed they had stock.  Delivery was said to be 5-7 days.  After 10 days I checked the status of the order and it had not shipped yet.  I spoke to customer service and was told it was an Amazon item and was on order even though when I placed the order they had plenty of stock.  They said it could take 4-6 weeks for the item to arrive and asked if I wanted to cancel the order, which I said no. Today I checked the status of my order and discovered Amazon cancelled the order in mid-September and never notified me.  Amazon has other suppliers selling the same item but at a higher price which they will not match.  This is not a good way to conduct business and I am very dissatisfied with Amazon.com.Beware of any and all purchases you make from Amazon as you may never receive them.

Purchased a printer on Amazon. Printer arrived in a "Home Depot" Box 2X the size with about 12 pieces of newspaper as padding. I contacted the seller over 9 times with no resolution. Printer had arrived smashed. Amazon told me that I had to send it back and pay the shipping. Amazon is horrible to deal with. All they do is email form responses computer generated.Never again will I order from them.

I have to say that i buy a lot from amazon and rarely have problems, in fact it is nearly always a good experience.  but when there is a problem their customer service seems worthless so i am giving them a poor rating simply because of their customer service.  Case in point--Our credit card company saw some funny charges so they stopped that day's charges and reissued the card.  unfortunately we had some orders that had just shipped from amazon and they completely freaked out.  They sent emails with specific instructions to add the replacement credit card to our account and then reply with the email with the last 2 digits of the new credit card to change the billing over.  Great except they also froze our account so we could not get in.  Several calls and emails to customer service were no help as everyone says they cannot unlock the account.  over a week later and we are still in this endless loop.  pathetic.  Every one of our other vendors handled this in a much more professional manner while amazon came across as being clueless.

My nightmare started when I first ordered a console from their site, after a week the tracking had shown "delivered" yet I did not receive my product. Amazon was quick to send out a replacement so I can receive it before my son's birthday (which is why I purchase the console) and I was very happy at the moment with their customer service. Time has come and the same thing happened (address error? carrier error? someone stealing it off my porch?) and when contacting Amazon I was accused of criminal activity. After several phone calls and plenty of promises I still have not received a refund. My last phone call was dealt with by Tanya who had extreme attitude. Not only was denying all that I've said, she shut the phone in my face after I sarcastically told the rep that it was nice to be told that I would not receive help. She simply said "thanks, bye bye" and immediately shut the phone in my face. This will not go unnoticed.

Amazon is in bed with Google. Try googling "Amazon Reviews"....good luck...not even Google Plus Reviews are available. Shame on you Gaagle!As to Amazon they are intentionally slowing their shipments to non-plus customers, to push them to pay $99....I know because I have been ordering from them for years.Latest example: today I got an item I ordered from Amazon for $2.99 that was shipped from China that came just one day after the $60 stuff from same order shipped by Amazon from good old USA.!!!???? Go figure. I am still waiting on another item from same order..........I am in Kentucky and its probably coming from Ohio......

I registered on amazon.co.uk and try to buy simple Sony Playstation 4. And on next day my account blocked, cause they think what i'm not real. They force me send them information about my card. I'm simple decent woman. Why i must send them this information?!

I will not be using amazin prime again. I used to buy off at least once a week. But they took money out of mine and my boyfriends account for amazing prime without our concent and now our son has to go days without what he needs until they give us our money back. Screw Amazon.

Amazon free shipping is the slowest shipping method available, I used to buy from amazon but their shipping times has changed drastically, my last order took three weeks to process and  ship.I made a comparison with Ebay and the same product, same price, free shipping but Ebay shipping was priority mail. This site has gone so far downhill in the past year or so it's not funny.  Extreme shipping times, misrepresented shipping times, wrong items and misrepresented items have been par for the course.  I have had to return 2 out of the past 6 items for being misrepresented on the site.  A current order has shown 9/22 as delivery date.  It's 9/23 and no item.  Amazon's answer is to "give it a couple more days."

I once loved ordering from amazon but its going down hill quickly. Im a prime memeber and the last few orders I have placed the package never arrived although it they said it was delivered. I have a door man and a camera for all deliveries. The packages never came. In one occasion the guy delivering it actually called me and to confirm the address he had thought the city (chicago) was the street on the address slip and when I corrected him still no package showed up. When I talked to amazon they said to wait 2 more days and if it still wasn't there they would send me another item. I pay for the prime membership so I can have my packages in 2 days and now its turned into at least 6 day delivery for the last 3 products. I no longer trush this company and will be canceling my membership.

And now they are telling me it is my problem not theirs. Beware of the new scam of amazon. I use to love it but now I am scared to even use my credit card with them.

i purchased a sharp microwave drawer and they canceled my order ..i waited three days to watch for shipping and they all the sudden cancelled with no explanation but was out of stock..it was priced at 899.00 then a slash through it said now 699.00 i bought. i bought and applied for amazon store credit .. it went right through .. now they have cancelled the item because i believe it was a false advertising as when i questioned them about it they said had no more..now i only see online for 1000.00 plus so my personal opinion is they decided not to accept my payment of 699.00..it was the price they made it i bought it and now two days later no microwave..never again with amazon to many third parties maybe not so much on the up and up..see ya amazon.ALL CUSTOMER SERVICE DID FOR ME WAS TELL ME I WAS SCREWED OUT OF THE ITEM .. discount direct was the seller ... poor seller

Amazon has some good items and prices but their delivery team - Amazon Logistics let them down. This particular order, the delivery man left my item outside the porch in the open air when I have requested it to be place inside the porch as a secured place.  Previous within the last 12 month, there had been 2 failed deliveries. Both times the delivery did not take place on the day they promised and I am a prime customer.

If I could give them 0 stars I would. Purchased aluminum diamond plate pickup truck bed rail protectors through Amazon from a company in GA named East Coast Jeeps. Parts arrived on 3 August, 2015 damaged so I contacted Amazon and East Coast Jeeps. It should have been easy to return damaged parts due to improper packaging, not so. They wanted pictures on two different occasions. Due to a lack of cooperation by East Coast Jeeps, I filed an A-Z guarantee with Amazon on 7 August. East Coast Jeeps delayed filing a damage claim with UPS until 10 August. I returned the parts via UPS on 12 August and immediately informed East Coast Jeeps and Amazon of the parts being out of my hands as I was requested to do. Here it is 17 August and East Coast Jeeps hasn't returned an email since 11 August and Amazon just tells me "they are looking into the matter" but no refund. Let it be known that East Coast Jeeps is selling parts that have been returned and are incomplete and are repackaging them and selling them as "new". The part I received was missing numerous parts and instructions let alone that it was not packaged with any protection inside the box, Not the way it came from the manufacturer. I am disgusted with Amazon. I have not been on hold with them for almost 30 minutes and no supervisor is available to deal with this issue. Guess if they ignore me I will go away.

Amazon.com is an overpriced store that claims to offer "free shipping" for Prime Members, yet they encourage sellers to include the shipping price in the cost of the item. Everything is much more expensive than your local grocery store. Additionally, if you complain, they go back and delete all of your consumer reviews to try and "punish" you. MAJOR review manipulation. Closing my Amazon account today!

Amazon used to be great. I used to rave about Prime and its benefits. But recently, things have changed. Prime is no longer two days. Logistics are a nightmare. Shipping is problematic.Case and point: I received a notification on my phone today (a Saturday) that UPS had made a delivery attempt (at 8am...on a Saturday). I didn't hear the bell, but I looked outside, and there was no evidence of a delivery attempt. I called UPS, and they said they've handed it off to the Post Office so it's their problem. As an Amazon customer, this amounts to a terrible experience on my end.Like I said, things didn't used to be this way. Amazon WAS great. They are no longer. I've set my Prime membership to expire, and will be moving as many of my purchases as possible away from Amazon to other retailers (both online and local).

Well, I bought HP ink from Amazon. I installed it in my ALL in One 6180 printer, which worked perfectly until now, and the cartridges leaked and ruined the printer. I place a review and Amazon refused to post it, saying it went against their policy. I guess the truth is not allowed. Here is the review that they refused:Ruined my printer. Leaked on first test. August 2015, August 3, 2015By C. S. Bastian (San Diego)Verified Purchase(What's this?)This review is from: LD © Remanufactured Replacement for Hewlett Packard (HP) 02 Ink Cartridges Set of 6 : 1 Black C8721WN, Cyan C8771WN, Magenta C8772WN, Yellow C8773WN, Light Cyan C8774WN, Light Magenta C8775WN (Office Product)This product should not be offered on Amazon. It has just ruined my printer. I may stop shopping on amazon if they do not offer to make good on replacement of my printer.I will add, I am waiting to see how the resolve this with me, but am extremely disappointed in the refusal to post a honest review. There is nothing abusive in it, and this hurts my trust in the company. Amazon apologized for my misfortune but will do nothing but replace the ink. Ink for a printer that no longer works. If I bought this ink from HP they would be replacing my printer. LD inks ruined my printer. and I now know my shopping on amazon comes with the same dangerous as buy from a stranger on craigslist. I have been a loyal shopper of Amazon and loved them up til now. A defective product manufactured to mimic HP destroyed my product. Looking back I don't see how this was not a counterfeit ink cartridges, as it registered as genuine HP, but is not. So is Amazon selling knock offs? Another question to consider. I plan on investigating this, and if there are violations pursue them.

Amazon has terrible policies. Especially their product review and return policy for sellers. Anyone in the world can go and give a product review on your product if there have ever purchased a product or not. What ends up happening is competition gives negative reviews under different names and agree customers about your policies make up negative reviews for revenge. As far as the return policy goes amazon sends you one email if a claim is opened and if you do not reply with in 7 days they give the buyer a full refund and let him keep the product no maker what the cost is or if there is actually something wrong with the product. Amazon should at least send more than one email it is easy to miss one email when you receive 10's of them from amazon daily, they should review the case before refunding, and should require the buyer to return the item before giving a refund. Ebay has much better return policy so if you want to sell stick to ebay. Amazon with suck away all your profits with their ridiculous policies

I am beyond disappointed with Amazon. I’ve purchased before and have spent a lot of money with you and this experience left a horrible taste in my mouth.  I paid for next day shipping on this item. I waited the whole day and it never showed up. I call the next morning 7/16/2015 and Amazon said it was out for delivery. I needed this item for an event that was taking place that weekend. I waited and waited on 7/16/2015 and I had to end up calling them back. Used to be biggest Amazon.com Fan...convinced many family and friends to become a prime member but I am done after this experience...Placed an ordered with next day shipping and 3 days later; there is no delivery and being told TOMORROW and TOMORROW by their department called customer service,

Edit on 08/10/2015:  In the past I always said that you can't beat Amazon customer service. No longer true for me, makes me wonder what is going on at Amazon. Amazon seems to be messing up more and more of late - poor packaging, items not as described from Amazon Warehouse deals, wrong items shipped and terrible customer service. It used to be easier, but not cheaper, to shop at Amazon than to buy from a local brick and mortar store but just not worth it anymore to me.Only makes sense to me to buy items that cost less than ~$10 from Amazon or bargain priced items.I plan on shopping online elsewhere and buying more locally. Many big box stores offer a free ship to store option. Seems easier to me to drive in to town to pick up purchases than to deal with the now, IMHO, terrible customer service from Amazon and then have to drive into town to drop the returns off at the UPS store or post office. Either way you end up doing a trip to town, why not buy for less locally or do a price match locally?Mistakes happen, just part of life, what matters to me is how mistakes are handled. IMHO Amazon no longer is dealing with their mistakes in a timely and fair manner.Guaranteed delivery dates are hit or miss, best Amazon seems to do is give you another month of Prime and more late deliveries.BTW I don't plan on renewing my Prime subscription come renewal time. Always have had Prime set not to auto renew which is the closest you can get to canceling. Prime is not like a a big name warehouse store membership, they will refund the membership fee if you are not happy, Amazon will not refund the fee to unhappy customers. Amazon fails to provide what you paid for and still keeps the $99 Prime membership fee...-----------------------Old Review:By reading reviews of amazon.com here it seems that many still don't understand that anyone can be a third party seller on Amazon.  IMHO buying from a third party seller on amazon, newegg, best buy, walmart or other etailers is like buying from an eBay seller.  Safest to just buy products that are "sold and shipped by amazon.com" and skip buying from third party sellers that might be scammers.I spend way too much at Amazon.  Every once in a while they do make an error but so far errors have been resolved quickly and fairly with a friendly email or sometimes two.Finally joined Prime about a year and a half ago.  Orders get to me quicker and every now and then I watch some of the movies and TV shows that Prime members get for free.  Selection of Prime videos is not great but oh well, you get what you get.  Prime videos are an added benefit, not their main business.Only difference I have noticed since joining Prime, other than the extra benefits like Prime instant video, is that packages leave the warehouse days sooner.  Customer service is just as good as before I joined Prime, 5 star plus!I tend to buy "Sold and Shipped by Amazon.com" products or every now and then something sold by a third party seller if Amazon is doing the shipping.    Buying directly from third party Amazon sellers usually is, to me,  like buying from someone selling stuff out of their bedroom on a famous Internet auction site. Got to love Amazon's customer service, of all the etailers I have shopped at for many years not one has exceeded Amazon when it comes to customer service.   If the little guys did half as well as Amazon I'd shop elsewhere more often as I would prefer to buy from small businesses instead of a big corporation.   A lot of small etailer's don't seem to have caught on how to do customer service and seem to want to start an argument rather than dealing fairly in a timely manner with issues.  A recent issue I had with returning a product that was shipped in error from an etailer that specializes in selling closeout tools has reminded me just what a great job Amazon actually does.  Almost seems to me as if the small etailers would rather people buy from Amazon rather than from them at times.9 time out of 10 Amazon prices seem to be lower than local or what shows up on a Google search.  I do get charged sales tax at Amazon  but still Amazon is usually the cheapest unless some etailer is selling what I am looking for for a limited time special price.Amazon has missed the promised delivery date a couple of time but a quick email to Amazon customer service has always resulted in a small cash credit being added to my account.

On Friday, April 17, 2015 before 8:00am, I placed 2 orders and paid additional money for next day delivery. Late Friday evening I received an email from Amazon that the items would be delivered at 8pm Saturday evening.  As luck would have it, the items did not arrive. I contacted Amazon's Customer Service department shortly after 8pm Saturday evening. I spoke with a first line representative, a supervisor and manager to explain that my shipments never arrived which were gifts for my niece's birthday party on Saturday.  I also explained that my niece waited all day to receive her gifts and was excited about her special day.  All 3 Amazon representatives told me that the delivery date and time were estimates, and that the items would arrive on Monday, April 20. Nowhere did it mention that the overnight shipping was an estimate.  The reason I asked for a manager is because the supervisor also said, "sometimes we get disappointed." This was unacceptable! I told her that adults understand, but children do not. Children are kids for a short time and look forward to birthdays and holidays. Had I known on Friday morning when I placed the order that delivery was going to be at 8pm not earlier in the day, I would have cancelled the order.  Such information was sent via email late Friday evening and should have been noted during the ordering process. A delivery time should be available when an order is placed.  Additionally, when the packages did not arrive by 8pm Saturday evening, I only learned by calling Amazon customer service that the packages would be delivered on Monday. Amazon did not take the initiative to notify me of the delayed deliveries. Amazon is running a scam called Subscribe & Save.  This is how Amazon advertizes it:  “When you order through our Subscribe & Save program, you'll: • automatically receive a new shipment of the item in the monthly intervals you select • get a discount on our everyday price • get free shipping on every Subscribe & Save shipment • pay for each order only when the item is shipped • have the option to cancel at any time.”This is meant to apply to consumables that you may need on a periodic basis.  In reality, Amazon will charge you 10 times the price on the next shipment in the hopes that you will use the product before you realize how much you were charged.  The fine print in the Terms and Conditions includes the following:  “The total cost charged to your credit card for each Subscribe & Save order will be the cost of the item on the day the order is processed.”  Sounds innocuous right?  In reality, Amazon interprets this to mean that they have the right to charge you whatever they want after the first shipment even if it is 10 times more than the price.  The scam is that, since the product is consumable, Amazon hopes that you will consume it before you realize how much they charged you, since the charge goes on your credit card and you will not see your statement until the end of your cycle.  Here’s how it works:  They charge you 10 times more for the item, you consume it, you find out how much they charged, you call, they say that you can return it if you like, but it’s too late because you already consumed it and they get to keep 10 times the price.  I ordered a box of chewing gum for $10 with Subscribe & Save with the expectation of receiving a box every month.  Next month, they sent me another box and charged me $100 instead of $10.  I was lucky enough to notice the charge before I opened the box.  I called and they said that there is no mistake, that they have the right to change the price of any item however they choose without notifying me because of the sentence in the Terms and Conditions saying that I will be charged the cost of the item on the day the order is processed.  Needless to say, I returned the item, got a refund, and swore off Subscribe & Save. I wonder how many people began consuming the product before they found out how much they were charged and then had to accept the charge because they could not return the item.  This sort of practice can be expected from a fly by night operation not from Amazon.  It is really unfortunate that Amazon would resort to this type of egregious scam.

I rarely write reviews, anywhere, but Amazon has finally done something that I cannot let slide. A brief history of my time with Amazon.com: I easily spend  $3-4000 there every year and have been doing so for many years. I'm an Amazon Prime member because I like free 2nd day shipping. Returns are fairly easy as well. Now, on to my issue. It is regarding Amazon's trade-in program. I recently purchased a new iPad and read decent reviews about Amazon's trade-in program, so I thought I would try it. It seemed a lot less painful that using eBay. I do use eBay but the trade-in program was ridiculously easy. I'm starting to understand why now. My original iPad was purchased brand new, from Apple.com in April 2010. When it arrived, I opened it using my nitrile gloves and immediately installed a screen protector and rear case plastic protector. Then, on top of the rear plastic, I put on my hard plastic case. When I removed all the protective covers, to send it to Amazon, it looked exactly like it did when I opened the Apple box in 2010. It was in mint physical and operational condition. It even shocked me a little. So, I felt 100% confident to request the most for this trade-in. It looks brand new, why wouldn't I want top dollar. So I send it in, in the original Apple iPad box and Apple shipping box. It had all original accessories and documentation. So, I check my email today and was notified that they are returning it to me because of "minor scratches". I beg to differ heavily on that! This iPad rarely left my room, much less experience anything to add wear and tear to it. So, I was thanking my stars that I clicked on the "return" button when it asked me if I wanted the lower value they offer or if I wanted it back. I want it back! I'm not getting low-balled and screwed out of $50.00 because Amazon hasn't seen an iPad in mint condition. I would be willing to bet good money that they have never issued the maximum dollar amount for pretty much anything that wasn't factory sealed. So, now I am off to start sourcing my goods elsewhere. I cannot trust a company that is this blatantly fraudulent. Instead of using my Amazon app and enjoying prime, I'll vote with my wallet and use google to find the same products elsewhere. They'll lose more than the $50.00 they should have given me on an obviously perfect trade-in. My advice to anyone considering using their trade-in program, know your product and opt to have it sent back because amazon will offer you the lowest price no matter what the condition. Don't sacrifice money for convenience. I'll be putting this baby on eBay and taking my chances. Good luck to everyone else.

I usually am very pleased with Amazon.com IF I am dealing directly with them. However, I am finding more and more that if I place an order that involves one of their partners, I'm taking a big risk. If problems develop, Amazon will forward on the complain but will not actively participate in resolving the problem. The first time I encountered a problem (which involved credit card fraud on the part of partner), I wrote the CEO of Amazon. Their response essentially stated that they had had good experience with the company and would not pursue my complaint.This time I ordered 13 boxes of Power Bars from Amazon's partner, bikesomewhere.com for over $150. Whereas the package arrived in a reasonable period of time, the 13 boxes inside were damaged to different degrees - enough so that I questioned the safety of the products. In fact, I checked the expiration dates on each box, suspecting they were way past their shelf life. Most of the boxes were not appropriately sealed, and you could see the bars in some of the boxes. The most damaged box had a bar missing, and end of the wrapper on the rest had been cut off - exposing the bars themselves! Clearly there is no quality control at this store, and I'm sure they are in violation of FDA rules.Amazon accepts no responsibility for these partner stores....You can only complete a complaint form online, and they forward the complaint to the offending store.From now on, I will only shop via Amazon itself. If the product goes through a partner store, I will not proceed.One of the questions in this survey was to rate my experience with Amazon's return policy. I gave it a "poor" rating because they are deferring to the partner store, and that store has yet to respond. I'd return the products if I could, but Amazon refuses to get involved, and bikesomewhere.com won't respond.

When I checked the tracking on Tuesday, I saw that it was listed as out for delivery - in KENT WA while I live in SPOKANE WA. I have shopped at Amazon for many years and have not changed my address for over 3 years - during this time I have always received my orders at this address, I did not change it at checkout.Needless to say, I am extremely unhappy with Amazon's handling of the order. Not happy with Amazon today:1. SuperSaver penalty: Amazon offers SuperSaver shipping on orders over $25.00. With SuperSaver, the _shipping_ date would have been July 12, whereas for standard shipping the _delivery_ date would have been July 12. In other words, delivery of an in-stock item was going to take 11-17 days, not 5-9.2. Problems changing an order: I decided to pay for shipping. To find out what the costs would be,  I first changed the order to two day shipping. But then I couldn't change to Standard or cancel. Apparently when you click two day shipping, the order is immediately in "process" and can't be changed on the web. After some time exploring  the Customer Service screens, I discovered a "Call Me Back" option, entered my phone number, and was called within five minutes (good!). Luckily the rep was able to change the order, but I was so fed up at that point that I told her to cancel it.3. Rebate switch: I had applied for an Amazon Visa to get a $40.00 rebate on my next purchase. After a while, I decided to re-order the item. Imagine my surprise when the advertised rebate for using the new Visa card was $30.00, not $40.00. I logged out, deleted cookies, and the next time I logged in, the rebate was up to $40.00 again. Amazon's been caught before raising prices for people who looked at an item once, then came back to order later. This looks like more of the same.

I am posting this email because I am so disgusted with Amazon's Customer Service and I want everyone to know how terribly the handled my business.Dear Amazon,I am not emailing looking for an answer to my complaints because I received one yesterday by phone, I am emailing because I am so disappointed with your service and I wanted you to know how disappointing it is that you do this to your customers. I am a “here and there” shopper, if I see an item listed for a good price, I’ll buy it. However, since it is the holidays and I am a college student, I need some cash for Christmas Shopping. I have a ton of DVD’s stacked up in my room so I figure, listing them on Amazon can’t do any harm, so I set up a seller account and list them on your website. I figure if they are selling for say $3.00, I will list them at $2.99, and so on. I did not think that they were going to sell at all so I had no expectations going into it. Then, almost instantly, my inbox was flooded with emails saying that some of my DVD’s were sold. I was so happy and instantly bought shipping accessories and packaged them and shipped them off to their destinations, I even made sure each DVD had a tracking number so as to satisfy the customer 100% and I would know when the packages got to their destinations safely. I was so happy that everything was selling and I was getting extra cash, but the shipping charges were very expensive, overall I probably spent $65.00 on shipping in a 3-day period. However, since the buyer pays for shipping and Amazon reimburses me, I figure that’s ok. Then, I go to look at my balance when this is all done, I am expecting about $120.00 profit, and I see that my balance, including shipping, is $112.00. I was shocked, I couldn’t believe that it was so low. Then I saw the Amazon fees, I was being charged up to $3.00 for a DVD that only sold for roughly $2 or $3! I figured that there must be some kind of mistake, so I called and talked to customer service. They explained to me that all of the fees were disclosed, and I made my mistake in not realizing that the prices that Amazon lists for the DVD’s selling price is including shipping. Also Amazon charges a 15% Commission Fee even though I was selling DVD’s as low as 80 cents. Well this is what I have to say to Amazon, that was a shady process. I imagine that tons of people a day make the same mistake that I do, and Amazon told me that if I list anything under or around $3, I will be losing money. If you were a great website that cared about your customers and not just about the customers who sell over 40 items in a month and do not get charged the 99 cent listing fee, you would give a warning right away to any customer who is listing anything for under $3.00. I am positive that no one on the site would list anything so low if they knew they were going to lose money. You can imagine how upset I was when I was not warned about this before, and told when it was too late, not only that, but Amazon could not do anything to help me. I am disgusted with the way Amazon handles business with customers like me, and never again will I make the mistake of listing my products on Amazon, whether it is under $3.00 or not, because Amazon does not care about its customers. I will make sure to spread the word on websites where customers look before posting items so that they do not make the same mistake that I did, you can be sure of that. One minute I am so grateful to Amazon because I am thinking that I will have over $100 in my pocket so that I can buy presents for my family, and then the next I am told that Amazon took half of that in “fees”. It really is the biggest disappointment you can give to a customer. As I said, I am not looking for any answers from you, I am simply letting you know that you get a 0% for customer service in my book and others will be informed so that no one will lose money to your website because you charge absurd fees for items that are only $1.00.Sincerely,A College StudentNo Longer an Amazon Customer

Ordered 46-inch television on Dec. 16, which was shipped out that same day via Pilot Freight (an Amazon sub-contracted shipping company).  Online tracking, both on Amazon.com and Pilotair.com showed no updates whatsoever for a week’s time, then, on Dec. 23, tracking showed “THIS SHIPMENT HAS BEEN DELIVERED” at 9:30am, and signed for by me.  While in reality the TV had never arrived, and I had signed for nothing.  I called Pilot Freight that evening to inquire, and the guy said, “Oh yeah…”, in a tone indicating he knew what had happened, and said to me my TV was in fact in Portland, OR (2 hours North of my location), and was safe and sound.  He said the TV would be delivered on Friday, the day after Christmas.  Friday passed with no call or delivery.  Online tracking continued to show my item had been delivered and signed for by me.  I called Amazon.com to inquire, and the outsourced difficult to understand English representative told me the false information presented on the Amazon tracking site was “Due to computer delays”, and that I’d be getting my TV “as soon as possible”.  Getting nowhere with that call, I sent an email to Amazon.com insisting that they show me my signature from the delivery that they claimed had already been made.  A day and a half later I received a call from Amazon indicating that the false information on their tracking site was the fault of the shipping contractor (Pilot), and that it was an “honest mistake”.  The representative said he couldn’t/wouldn’t provide me with a copy of the delivery signature, and that the TV would be delivered on Monday, 12/29.  End of call.    Shortly thereafter, the field “Signed for by:”, which had previously shown MY name, was changed to someone else’s, but the site continued to show that the TV had already been delivered on 12/23 at 9:30am.  Monday passes, and no call from the shipping company to arrange for delivery, and no TV had arrived.  Various items on both the Amazon and Pilot tracking site were changed, however.  I call Pilot freight again, and they say they can’t/won’t produce the signature showing that I had originally signed for delivery on 12/23, and that the error was the result of a new employee improperly entering information into their system(s).  Meanwhile, some time on 12/29, the online tracking on Amazon.com and Pilotair.com showed that my TV had been delivered on December 31, 1969 at 3:59:59pm.  (I’m not joking.)  I allow Tuesday to pass, and no call to arrange for delivery was made, and, obviously, no TV delivery.  Then, that evening, I get a message from the freight company indicating that they had my TV, but it didn’t match the TV I had ordered.  They apparently had a Samsung LN46A630, NOT the LN46A650 which I had clearly ordered, originally.  They requested a call back, asking what I wanted to do about it.  Upon my return call, I told them to take the TV back; I had had enough of this exercise of total ineptitude.  I called Amazon to cancel the order that evening, and was told by the outsourced representative that he couldn’t fully process the cancellation, as that would require a manager who was not on duty at the time.  I was told to call back the next day to arrange for cancellation.  Upon my call on 12/31, they didn’t have record of my cancellation, so I had to once again furnish the Amazon rep with the information needed to cancel the order.  I was told to call yet ANOTHER number, this time a U.S. center, to finalize cancellation of order.  So I called it, demanded cancellation and full refund, and was granted my request.  Although the rep said it would take unit they get the TV back for me to receive my refund, which is a dubious requirement given the incompetence of their shipping contractor in the first place. Overall I’m shocked and extremely angry over this transaction.  I ordered my television on a specific date so that I would receive it in time for a bowl game that I, friends, and family had been looking forward to for some time.  So Amazon and Pilot effectively shafted our plans, and blunted enjoyment of the gathering and event.  A rude dose of Amazon.com holiday cheer, if you will.  Another reality is, while indeed small in amount, Amazon has been making money on MY money, while never delivering the TV I paid for in full.  As such, I intend to ask them for the interest I otherwise would have been making, as it’s MY money.  I want it. To conclude, I shall never trust Amazon again, and am absolutely beside myself in realizing the incompetence they’ve demonstrated over this entire transaction.  Even at this point in time, the Amazon tracking site shows that my television WAS delivered--  This time it shows that my TV was delivered on 12/31 at a time that hasn’t even arrived yet at the time of this writing.  Truly incredible…

Beware clicking on any offers for Amazon.com credit as they are providing your information to other credit card companies.  I have been a long time Amazon.com customer.  Even if I'm looking at an item on another site I look to see if Amazon.com has it for less before I buy.       Recently I clicked on a link on one of their product pages offering $25 off your next purchase by applying for an Amazon.com credit card.  I looked it over and decided to apply.  I was still on Amazon.com's website when I filled out the application.  It was supposed to take 30 seconds for approval, but after that time it told me they would contact me.  I just assumed I had been turned down, though I didn't know why as my credit score is over 700.     Several weeks after applying I received a call.  The caller stated they were with Amazon.com and asked if I still wanted the credit card I had applied for.  I told them yes and they processed it for me at that time.  When I received the card it was an Amazon.com Store Card and indicated that it was actually a different company, GEMoney.com.  I didn't think much about it as I believed they were just processing the credit purchases for Amazon.com.  It even indicated that Amazon.com would automatically switch my default payment method to this new card, which they did.     When I received my first bill I noticed that I didn't receive a $25 credit on my first purchase.  I made several calls and eventually was told by a GEMoney.com representative that this was a different card, I had an Amazon.com Store Card and the $25 off first purchase was only for an Amazon.com Visa card, so I was told I wasn't eligible for the $25 off promotion.  That didn't sound right so I called Amazon.com and spoke to a customer service representative who would only identify himself as Ace.     I was on the phone for nearly an hour, much of it on hold, before he finally told me the same thing, I had a different card than the one I had applied for.  I was shocked that they would provide my customer information to other companies to solicit credit card applications, but it got worse.  He told me they have three different Amazon credit cards and if I understood him correctly they provided my information to at least those three other companies.  I received a rash of pre-approved credit offers at about the same time I was called about the Amazon.com card so I really don't know to what extent the private information I provided them with was shared with other companies but it does worry me.     I think it is just horrible that they would provide my personal information to other companies after I clicked a link to apply for thier card and filled out the application on their site.  To allow another company to call me and represent itself as Amazon.com when it isn't is simply fraud.  It is a simple bait and switch, they offer a $25 off your first purchase promotion to obtain the needed information for a credit card application and then provide that information to other companies.  At no point was I told I wouldn't receive $25 off my first purchase.       I've been a customer of Amazon.com for a long time, but I'm really going to have to give some thought before making any more purchases.  I have already deleted the Amazon.com Store Card as my default method of payment and I won't be using it again.

"BOYCOTT AMAZON.COM...!!!!!!!"Like one of the other reviewers, my Amazon.com account was suddenly closed without warning by the account services people at Amazon because I had returned too many items that were damaged due to poor packaging.  For people shopping at Amazon.com, I just want to warn you that unless you have low expectations for the quality of the products you purchase, this is not the place where you want to shop.  Yes, Amazon.com does offer cheaper prices for certain products (NOT ALL PRODUCTS) on their sites, but as the old addage goes, you get what you pay for.  And don't expect them to change their habits of using CHEAP packaging for the items you puchased because I was never able to convince them to use better packaging after all the incidents that I had with damaged items purchase thru them or their affiliated sellers.  They will only penalize you, the consumer for returning damaged items too many times.  Most people (just like myself) think that Amazon.com have a good returns policy with the so call "A-Z buyer protection plan", but the real truth is that they treat the consumer as a means to squeeze money from rather than to provide good service to.  It all sounds good, but try returning damaged or defective products a few times in a row and your account could be SHUT DOWN without even a WARNING!!!!Frankly, I was always hesitant to shop with them and this experience only confirms and reinforces my apprehensions about shopping on their site.  "BUYER BEWARE...!!!!"To all buyers out there, just be sure you don't return the items you buy from Amazon.com regardless of damage or defects or risk loosing your account.

Watch out for Amazon's partner merchants! I've had pretty good results when I ordered from Amazon itself (books, movies, etc) but I've had all kinds of problems with order fullfillment from merchants who use Amazon's portal. For this year's disaster: on December 13 I ordered a gift pack from Fireworks Popcorn through Amazon. Delivery was promised between December 19 and 24. I received an automated e-mail message from Amazon on Dec 25, stating that my order hadn't been shipped and I wouldn't be billed. I sent a reply back, asking for some information on my order and that apparently went to a human being. The next day I got a reply from customer service at Fireworks Popcorn, stating that they got buried in orders from Amazon and just couldn't deliver in time for Christmas. They "promised" to get my order out on Dec 26. On Friday December 28 I got an e-mail from Amazon telling me that my order finally went to UPS late that day and I do have a UPS number for the shipment. With the New Years holiday, and the fact that the package is going to the DelMarVa peninsula (which seems to add an extra day or two to delivery), delivery is promised for January 4. So my Christmas present won't even make it in time for New Years Day.The comments I read on Amazon's merchant feedback leave me with the impression that Fireworks Popcorn is a small specialty company that decided to go national by listing with Amazon. They don't have any idea how to fill large numbers of holiday gift orders in a timely manner. Hiring  some extra help might be a good start for next year.I can't speak to the product itself, but if delivery for a holiday is a concern to you, you might want to look at another vendor who understands how to do e-commerce.  1/3/08 - I checked Amazon this AM and it looks like Amazon has stopped selling Fireworks Popcorn procucts (everything is listed as "currently unavailable") Good job by Amazon in pulling the plug on those folks.

I understand that Amazon is a very large company, and thus they cannot personally attend to every order to ensure its proper fulfillment, but what has just happened to me is quite ridiculous. I will quickly recap.I placed an order on or around September 26, 2007 for twenty-nine children's books for my wife's kindergarten classroom for just $21. Amazon was running a 4-for-3 sale, and on top of that, many of the books were priced at a dollar or below. We were ecstatic, and even happier after we ordered enough to receive Free Super Saver Shipping.Several days later, I received an email notifying me that Amazon would be unable to fulfill my order thanks to having been "unexpectedly out of stock in copies of one or more items that we can offer at the discounted price." Nineteen of the books on my order at this point were cancelled. To make matters much worse, a shipping charge of $12.90 had been added to the order since it no longer totalled enough money (a matter of Amazon's own mistake, not mine), bringing the grand total for TEN books to $24, three dollars more expensive than I was previously slated to receive TWENTY-NINE books for. I was offered a $10 credit toward a future purchase, which helps to some extent, but considering that the actual adjusted price of the books is around $3-$4 apiece, that's only good for around three of the nineteen books I had lost.I was able to call and eventually have the shipping charge dropped, and so I signaled my contentedness and went on with things. Then, later, I logged on to find that further changes had been made to my order. Now, only TWO BOOKS were left on the order, and the total, including a shipping charge ONCE AGAIN, came to $8.So in summation, I went from a fantastic 29 children's books for my wife's classroom for just $21 to TWO books for $8, minus a $10 credit.Am I supposed to be content with this? At the very least I would think Amazon could seek to honor the original price quoted on just TEN of the books...I truly cannot believe Amazon changed my order once again even after the first issue we had worked out! This is ridiculous, quite frankly, and I am not the type of person who typically complains. What a joke.Amazon, I can understand that you might have made a pricing error here, and I honored your initial correction of the matter, but this is simply unnecessary. There has got to be a better way to deal with this than once again trying to charge me shipping. Now, rather than receive29 children's books for my wife's classroom for each less than a dollar, I am set to receive TWO books for roughly four dollars apiece.No thank you, I think I will simply take my business elsewhere--and YOU SHOULD TOO!This is not the first time this has happened to me or a friend/family member. Amazon readily cancels orders thanks to their policy on pricing errors and other mishaps without even so much as a compensation of some sort--regardless of how insignificant the error might have been. If you order from them, expect their system to screw you over in some fashion if there ever is a problem with your order. In my example, they tried to charge me $13 in shipping that was originally supposed to be waived, and that was AFTER they cancelled about half of the items in my order. They can and will do the same thing to you--it happens literally all the time. DO NOT order from Amazon without watching your order like a hawk, and be prepared to do your shopping all over again somewhere else if by some chance something goes wrong (which happens more than you might think).

On March 5, 2007, I ordered a new MacBook Pro 15.4" 2.16GHz Core 2 Duo notebook from Amazon, with overnight shipping for $2003.98 worth of gift certificate funds.  A couple of weeks later, I started getting kernel panics all of the time, so I took it down to the Apple store.  I was told there that it was most likely a bad motherboard, which was a common issue, that would be fixed under AppleCare, but it would take about a week to fix, so the Genius encouraged me to return it for replacement to Amazon.  After saving all of my things, I packed it up and sent it back to Amazon.  A week later, my gift certificate balance rose to $1446.00, $557.98 was missing.  I contacted Amazon, and they told me that since the funds expired during the time I had the notebook, there was nothing they could do.  However, since they had never told me this in the first place, I decided to contact the BBB.About two weeks after contacting the BBB, I recieved an email that because I had returned so many things to Amazon, my account was now closed and I was now out any funds on my account.It is true that I had returned two of these notebooks before, but they really did have issues.  One had a bad chip of memory on the graphics card, which would cause corruption in 3D applications, and the other had issues with I/O, mainly IR communication, both of which were hardware issues, and vital to the opearation of the computer. After this fiasco, I'm perfectly fine with no longer shopping at Amazon, even after being a customer since around 1997, but being out over $2000 is a HUGE problem.

I wanted the hard-to-find DVD "Santa Claus" (cult classic from Mexico ca 1958) on 28 October 2006.  I followed Amazon's recommendation and added other items to my cart so that I could get free shipping.  The estimated shipping on the Santa Claus DVD was 2 to 4 weeks, and I didn't have a problem with that.  It's probably not a very popular item.A month went by and I noticed on 27 November they had broken the order into 2 shipments.  Both shipments were in the "ship soon" status.  I didn't like this development so I sent them an email that said, in effect, "ship it all at once or don't ship any of it."  12 hours later the 3 non-Santa items had started "the shipping process" and the Santa DVD was now scheduled to arrive "after December 22nd".On the morning of November 28 I had a resopnse to my email that did not address my specific concern.  I went to the page where you can request a "Call Me" phone call from Amazon's Customer Support.  Before clicking on it I went to my orders page and saw that the 3 non-Santa items were still "shipping soon" but the Santa DVD was not scheduled for delivery until AFTER 25 DECEMBER.This was unacceptable to me and needless to say I was upset so I went ahead and had someone from Amazon call me.  I spoke with John who was nice enough, even though I feel he lied to me.  He said he had a 90% success rate in getting items that had not actually been shipped yet stopped before they went on the truck.So today I have a tracking number and it is up to me now to make sure somebody is home to refuse delivery from USPS and then wait for Amazon to credit my card with a refund.  I think Amazon engages in deceptive business practices and fraud.  I relied on their statement that the items would ship in 2-4 weeks.  I relied on their recommendation to order extra things to get free shipping.  I relied on their email feedback system to head off a potential problem with the order.I have filed a complaint with both my state's department of consumer protection and the Federal Trade Commission.  I advise anyone thinking about ordering from them to be very careful when looking at Amazon's shipping and delivery estimates.  It's a proven fact that they lie about these dates.

Amazon.Com once known as a pioneer in web commerce has fallen to a point of ridicule. By out-sourcing their so-called "customer service" they have effectively buried any notion of fair business practice. Their method is one off systematic excuse-making, false hope, and unfulfilled online promises. Amazon's guaranteeed delivery service is simply fraudulent. They will lie to you on the telephone in this aspect just to keep the customer service ratings high for their overseas call centers. Like Dell computer, this company will quickly learn the hard lesson of outsourcing customer service.I ordered a Canon G7 camera on November 22 and was offered 2-day GUARANTEED delivery (for recipet on Monday, Nov 27th). It is now Saturday, November 25th and the package is sill sitting idle at Amazon.Com. In the UPS system my package is specified as a GROUND delivery. A delivery which will not move over the long holiday weekend.Amazon.Com will tell you the package is in transit when it is not. In transit only means the company has transmitted the tracking number to UPS. It does not mean the package has beeen picked up, or is on the way. I posted a very factual and positive review of my experience, including the inadequate packaging, the Amazon partial refund (a positive), the positive features of the product, and a recommendation that other consumers should buy the extended warranty. After several more days, I emailed and asked why it wasn't posted.To my absolute amazement, the response indicated that "...your review of "Haier HVB050ABH Designer Series Wine Cellar with 50-Bottle Capacity" was removed because your comments in large part focused on your personal opinions of the subject matter, rather than reviewing this item."!  After several email exchanges, including a revision I did to my review, which I absolutely didn't consider necessary but made in the spirit of things, my review was still not posted.Today I received a note from Amazon.com informing me that they have censored (edited) my review and posted it. However, if you would prefer to have your review removed rather than edited you may do so online.”.  Their edits removed any mention of the damaged product receipt, the inadequate packaging, the fact that Amazon.com agreed to give me a partial refund, and several other objective facts intended to help other customers.  That was the last straw. I have used Amazon many times before, mostly for books, and have been a very happy customer in general.  Their web site is fast, and they usually have been pretty pleasant to deal with.I wanted to buy a new TV for my mom this Christmas who lives in Fresno, and even though my local Fry's had the set I wanted on sale at the same price Amazon did, I didn't want to have to try and pack it into my SUV along with all the other presents and luggage for the trip to Fresno.  Plus, as an AMEX customer, I had a 25% off coupon that would work at Amazon.com that would help offset the shipping expense (the amex coupon maxes out at $150, and the shipping was around $130).  Though I had never ordered such stuff from amazon.com before, based on my past experience, I decided to go ahead an place an order.I ordered the Sony KDF-E42A10 from Amazon on the 18th, and the website indicated it shipped on the 20th, not via fedex by via Eagle Global Logistics.  Even though Amazon's web site showed the TV shipped on the 20th, the Eagle tracking site didn't show anything other than the fact they'd receieved it.  After 2 days of no activity, and seeing some reviews on Amazon about based experiences with Eagle, I started calling Eagle.  They aren't the easiest to deal with.  They said that even though there was no tracking info available, sometimes items are shipped in containers where the individual items aren't scanned.  I called the Dallas EGL site and they said it wasn't there, but could be on a truck to Sacaramento, or to LAX.  After several more days of no activity, and more calls to the various Eagle locations to check status, I finally reached someone who took responsibility and dug into everything.  he did dock checks at all the possible facilities, and couldn't find it.He found out that Amazon generates a tracking number and shipping manifest with them before the actual item shows up on their docks, so he couldn't even tell if it had ever been delivered to them by Amazon.  Apparently sometimes things get "lost" between Amazon and the shippers.  He said it was unlikely at this point the TV ever was shipped (this is on the 27th, 7 days after the order supposedly shipped).  After sending Amazon a note on this fiasco outlining the fact that we were only here a couple more days and that the whole point was to get the TV here when I could hook it up for her and that they needed to find out what was going on, Amazon responded that the shipper contacted them and said they lost the item, and that Amazon could either cancel the order or expedite a new TV.  I tried reaching them on their undocumented 800 number (sounded like it was in India), but all they did was send email to the shipping dept...  Amazon only seems to want to deal with email, and email through their web interface which is very painful and take a long time between responses.  Even though they first said they would expedite shipment of a replacement, now they say it's too big to be shipped by Fedex or UPS so they can't expedite it after all, and they will cancel the order.  This is despite the fact that fedex freight can do next day shipment.  Then there is the issue of the AMEX coupon I used.  If they are going to cancel it, then I want my coupon back.  I have yet to get a response from them on this.Bottom line, I am very disappointed with Amazon here.  It's made worse by the fact that noone there will just pick up the phone and call me (I included my cell phone in my notes), instead causing me to waste a lot of time checking email and trying to figure out what to do next.  It could have been handled so quickly.  I have concluded that if you want to buy things like books from Amazon, that works fine, but they aren't set up yet to do a good job on items like TV's and other things they can't ship the way they ship books.  Eagle is a terrible shipper, and Amazon's shipment process with them can allow mistakes to not get caught and drag on for days because noone knows where the item could be.  Stay away from Amazon for things like TV's and electronics.  I will update this when we get this finally resolved.

There have been a lot of postings about the Leatherman deal and I’m sure mine won’t be the last.  I’ve purchased around 50 items during the last 3 years (35 of these in the last year) from Amazon and it has been one of the three Internet retailers that I have used and trusted the most.  These are guys where when I see an item I want, I can place an order in about 30 seconds-I know the password and the screens, my CC# and street address are already there, I trust them so I don’t have to research them or worry about what is going to happen, etc.I ordered an item for the first time from the Home Shopping Network (HSN.com) around a month ago, got a confirmation e-mail from them with an arrival date, then 5 days later got an e-mail saying they didn’t have the item and canceling the order.  The first thought in my head was that Amazon would never do this to me.When the same thing happened with me on the Leatherman deal from Amazon, I was very, very disappointed and surprised.  It was the same disappointment I felt with the HSN deal (ordering something, being told it was in the system and receipt was eminent, then getting the e-mail saying it wasn’t going to happen-please shop with us again, etc), only worse because it was with a Company that I really trusted.  I know it is just a company and not some personal friend, but I did really trust them.  The surprise came from Amazon alienating someone like me that has become an increasingly frequent buyer and fairly embedded (I even got an Amazon credit card).About the price.  I didn’t know how much it should have cost, but I did know that it was a very good deal.  My most recent purchase was a drill where Amazon showed a list price of $170, that they were selling for $75.  I have seen many items where Amazon had a sale price of around 33% of the item’s list price.  Now looking at Costco.com I see a similar large Leatherman for $49.  Getting that one and another small micro for $26 from Amazon was a very, very good price, but not over the line of believability (like seeing a plasma TV for $300) and no more of a deal than some of the other examples.  I figured that they got a truckload and were selling them at cheap to keep people interested in Amazon or attract new customers.The e-mail from Amazon saying the price was a mistake, canceling the large Leatherman from my order, saying that this wasn’t a problem because their legal terms allowed it, and hoping I would continue to shop with them was insulting and pretty abrupt.  It also didn’t tell me that the “micro” Leatherman was still on the order at the regular price- I had to find that out on my own.  With either 1) a new proposed, acceptable price for the deal which I might have gone for, or some concession (store credit, free overnight shipping on the next item, etc.) this whole thing would not have left such a bad taste in my mouth.  I won’t say that I will never buy anything from them again, but they are definitely now in the pack with everyone else and not one of my very trusted internet retailers.

With good to great prices and free shipping on almost anything over $25, Amazon USED to be my first and last stop for books and lots of other stuff.Not any more.I live near one of their major warehouses, and even with free shipping, I could usually count on getting my stuff within 2-3 days of place an order. But ever since they started touting this "Amazon Prime" shipping scam on their front page, they've been deliberately sitting on my "free shipping" orders for as long as possible. Orders of items that are listed as "usually ships in 24 hours" now sit for days and days waiting to be fulfilled...the winner so far was an order of two such items that sat at their warehouse for NINE DAYS before leaving. It now regularly takes 10 days to two weeks to get the same orders that used to come in just a few days.I can only assume this is a scheme to try and drive their semi-regular customers like me into shelling out $80 for Prime, but to me it just seems like a good way of alienating Amazon's long-time shoppers. Guess what, Amazon? You may have been the only game in town back when I first started shopping there in '98, but not any more. And you can rest assured I'll be shopping at those other stores first.

DO NOT PURCHASE CELL PHONES FROM AMAZON.COM! I've used amazon for books and CDs and they've been great, but their cell phone operation is A MESS! They send me an email there's a problem with my credit check.  I call them, they need more info, fine 0 give them more info.  Another email in 2-3 days, still problems with credit check.  i call them (long wait and no direct number for cell phone dept. and their phone support # is hell to find), they tell me they don't know what the problem is (??) and I should AT&T.; I call AT&T;, they say there is no problem, the credit check went just fine.  Another call to amazon, more emails, my order is already 2 weeks delayed (althought the site says ships in 24 hours), lots of wasted time and nerves.  Finally they ship the order.  IT NEVER ARRIVES!!!  I check the tracking number, it never left their warehouse.  I call again, they say they cannot locate the package, but I should cancel the order and place another one (!!!), and they will give me $50 discount for the trouble.  I do that and the order finally arrives, 3 weeks later, although I should have received it 24 hours later.Now, that was the first time, and I should have learned my lesson, but no, their rebates are too good.  Now a month ago I want Treo 650, I see their price is the best, but I also want to switch my service from AT&T; to Cingular and have them migrate me.  Amazon says sure we can do it. I don't believe them, call Cingular and they say no, amazon cannot do it, you will end up with two accounts and contracts.  Call amazon again, yes, they are sure they can migrate.  I ask for proofs in writing, they send me several convoluted emails.  Ok, I decide to take the risk, place the order. SAME THING ALL OVER AGAIN! There's a problem with my credit check email. Need to call them. I call them, they dont' know what is the problem (!) again, need to call cingular. I call cingular - there was never a credit check ran on my account in theri system. Call amazon back - no straight answer.  The phone was supposed to ship in 24 hours, it has been already 5 days of frustration, I ask them to upgrade the shipping, they refuse, saying the time on the site is quoted from the time the order is completed, and my order is not yet complete.That was too much. I canceled the order, drove to a cingular store, and bought the phone, did the migration in 10 minutes and walked out with a perfectly working phone and migrated account.What have I learned today: Amazon should stick to selling books and CDs!

No promised rebate and no response on why no promised rebate -On November 21, 2004 I purchased from Amazon.com a Lexar 512MB compact flash memory card.  The price was discounted based on a $20 rebate from Amazon.com. I mailed in the rebate on December 1, 2004.  The rebate terms were for a purchase of the item "between 11/18/04 and 11/27/04" with the rebate requests "postmarked by 12/27/04." I've scanned all the materials involved, including the stamped enveloped used for mailing.  Not thinking about it, as is often the case with rebates, since they have a built in multi-week to multi-month delay, I only recently realized that I had never received the $20 promised by Amazon in the sale. I can't stress this fact enough. I never would have made this purchase if not for the Amazon.com promise of a $20 rebate. Without the rebate, the sale would not have been a "sale." Checking the scan of the filled rebate form I noticed an Amazon related web address to submit inquiries regarding rebates.  http://amazon.rebatestatus.com/contactus.aspxUsing this Amazon inquiry web form, a couple of weeks ago I twice requested information about may rebate (March 4 and 8, 2005).  I am yet to receive a response. Not a response of any kind.I included in the comments section of the form all pertinent information regarding the sale.  Note that this is a sale from Amazon.com and a rebate from Amazon.com and so the validity of the sale and rebate is easily determined directly by Amazon.com though I would be more than happy to provide the scans of the rebate materials.  But there hasn't even been the courtesy of a response from Amazon.com regarding the rebate.My options at this point seem slim.  I could spend thousands to sue Amazon.com for the $20 they promised to provide as a rebate. Class action suits, though unlikely, are apparently even less likely with a new class-action law. Do you think these are factors in Amazon.com's completely ignoring its promised rebate and request for information regarding said rebate promise?I strongly urge anyone considering a purchase from Amazon.com involving a rebate to consider the results I've gotten.  Perhaps I should have used some sort of return receipt mail, but that in itself adds to the cost and effort involved in having a company simply follow through on a promise it made. And, since I haven't received the courtesy of a response from Amazon.com, I have little reason to believe that it's the postal service that is somehow lax in this matter.--------------------------------------------------Update: March 17, 2005, 5:35 PM ESTWow!!!5 hours after I make this post (I didn't check the exact time it actually appeared) I get an email from the rebatestatus site.  So I'm back at the beginning of the process.  But I guess that's better than being at the end, stiffed.  "Isn't that special?"Thanks ResellerRatings for the voice you provide.

Once upon a time I believed Amazon.com to be a great company. Their prices and service were absolutely great. Recently I have had cause to reconsider my opinion.For the past two years Amazon.com has seen fit to botch my Christmastime order. Last year I ordered around 10 items totaling several hundred dollars in merchandise, all of which was guaranteed to be delivered by Christmas. Apparently there was a problem with one item, so Amazon saw fit to delay my entire order until that one item arrived. So instead of a guaranteed Christmas delivery I received all my Christmas presents in January. All the time this was going on my order sat in limbo, unable to be canceled because it was being filled. The point to this is that Amazon.com violated two FTC laws regarding catalog and internet sales. You cannot hold someones order for over a month without nofifying them of a problem. Secondly you MUST give your customer the option to cancel the order if you delay the order for a month. They did neither of these things, and now I am regreting the fact that I didn't file a complaint with the Federal Trade Commission.Now comes this Christmas. I ordered a DVD/VCR combo player on October 31st. The player was listed as in stock shipping in 1-2 days. When I purchased the player I used a $30 gift certificate that I had received with my Amazon.com credit card. So two weeks go by and the player has not been shipped. I get an email from Amazon stating that there has been a problem in obtaining the DVD player and I need to approve a delay in my order. I went to the Amazon.com page for the DVD player and sure enough the status of the player had gone from "in stock ships in 1-2 days" to "out of stock, more in soon." Now obviously they never had the player in stock in the first place. If I don't want to suffer the delay I have the option of canceling the order, but then I would lose my $30 gift certificate. So I approve the delay, and after another two weeks my delivery estimate has now gone to January of next year. This is no good for a Christmas Present.SOOO, I email their customer service department and request that they change my order from the DVD player I ordered to another one that was IN STOCK. They refused to do so. I have to cancel my current order, and replace it for another DVD player. BUT since they have jerked me around for a month the $30 gift certificate I used in the original order has since expired and cannot be reused in my new order.Now what do you think of a company that treats their customers this. They could have shipped part of my order instead of sitting on the whole thing last year. They could have obeyed the laws of The United States of America. They could have had their stock listed correctly. They could have admitted that they had made a mistake and corrected it. Instead, each and every time, Amazon.com chose to screw me over as a customer. I say to you beware, sooner or later this will happen to you.

I apologize in advance that my post is somewhat lengthy, but I think it's important the story be told in full.My wife and I ordered four items (three books and a piece of software) from Amazon on August 18. All items were listed as "in-stock" and available to ship within 24 hours. Ten days later we hadn't received the packages yet and hadn't received shipment confirmation or a notice of delay from Amazon, so we checked the "Your-Account" page. Sure enough, the items hadn't even shipped yet. We emailed customer support, which gave us a boilerplate apology and no specific explanation for the delay. We were hoping Amazon would do the right thing and bump our shipping up to overnight or next-day air, but customer service made no such offer. After our prodding, the next day the items were sent out UPS ground and Airbourne.Dissatisified that Amazon wouldn't give us an answer about why the shipment was delayed so long, we sent two additional emails to customer service. Again, we received two boilerplate apologizes and explanations about how shipping timeframes aren't guarantees but estimates. But stretching 24 hours into 240 hours seems too big a mistake for just being a problem in estimation.In one of our emails with Amazon, we requested a phone number so we could speak with someone about this issue. As some of you have already mentioned, Amazon doesn't make a phone number available on its web site, but fortunately Amazon did provide it when asked--the number is 1-800-201-7575, by the way, in the US and Canada, not that it will do you any good. So, next, we called customer service at Amazon to find out what was going on with our shipment. Finally, we found out that because we selected Super Saver shipping that our order was supposed to be delayed 3-5 days, though the service rep couldn't account for why the order had been delayed for 10 days. She also couldn't point us to a place on the Amazon web site where it mentions that Super Saver shipments take longer to ship out. She said, "I think it's in a pop-up somewhere." After navigating the site again, we did discover a link (not a pop-up) that mentions Super Saver shipments are delayed 3-5 days, but we believe such a statement should be made prominently when the user selects the preferred shipping method. In addition, availability and delivery estimates should be adjusted to reflect this shipment option.We asked this customer service rep if we could speak with a manager. She said we could but told us we'd have to call back because she couldn't work the phones to transfer the call.When we did call back, we spoke to a manager (which Amazon calls an "order specialist"). We reached Leroy, who, when we asked why our shipment had been delayed more than 3-5 days, said, "I have no idea. I'm not in distribution." He was puzzled why we'd be concerned about the delay: "The shipment's only a few days late. That's not too bad." He offered only a $5 discount on our next purchase as compensation for the error, although he already knew by this point we'd never order from Amazon again. Some compensation!I asked Leroy if I could speak with his supervisor, and he said I could but she wasn't in. He told me that his supervisor, Marsha, would call me the next evening, and that I couldn't call her because she doesn't have a phone number. I asked him if he was certain Marsha would call us the next evening. He guaranteed she would. So I waited around the next evening, but Marsha never returned my call.Honestly, I have never dealt with a more inept company than Amazon.com. If you ever have any difficulties with an order, don't expect a direct answer, and don't expect anyone to resolve the issue to your satisfaction. And, if you select Super Saver shipping, don't expect to receive your items when they're supposed to arrive. We finally received part of our shipment on September 4, and the remainder is supposed to come sometime next week--Leroy guaranteed it, for what his word's worth. At this point, my wife and I have agreed to send all the items back and buy them from a more reputable reseller, even if doing so means paying more money. We hope never to deal with Amazon again.

Thats a very long 24 hr expected ship time.  Looked for 20 min trying to find a contact phone number so I could at least yell at someone, lo and behold, no phone number.  If I could of talked to someone and if they had contacted me a little sooner I might not of cancelled my order.  From now on its Newegg.

I figured Amazon.com, being such a reputable company, would not cause me any problems but this was not the case.  I tried to apply a gift certificate to my order online, following the exact instructions they have on their website on how to do this.  There was some sort of error though, and the certificate was not applied.  It told me that I could not enter another certificate although it wasn't applying the one I had entered.  Anyways, I decided to call customer service to clear up the issue before my order shipped.  Surprise! They have no number to call.  They only have email assistance.  They figure they must have every possible customer service scenario covered on their customer service page so no need to have phone support!  Anyways, I emailed and explained my situation but they basically blew me off.  They treated me like it was my fault the gift certificate wasn't applied, as if I'm some kind of moron.  I wrote back explaining exactly what I did, which was in accordance with their instructions bit again they emailed me back refusing to apply the gift certificate.Is it me? It's them right?  Obviosuly there is a disagreement.  How hard is it for them to take my gift certificate, which is prepaid revenue to them I might add, and apply it to my order?  Even if I was an idiot and didn't follow instructions, which is not the case here, why are they fighting me on this?  That is poor customer service.  This is the problem with big companies.  Sometimes they just don't give a crap about some tiny customer and try to make them go away once they have your money in hand.  Thanks Amazon.  I'll be back to your site for sure.
so so customer service, not very impressive. Amazon will take your money by strictly adhering to their policies, even if a grey area was involved. They don't give customers the benefit of the doubt.
